comments.commentBody:
I have a feeling that time will not treat Andy's officious take on Gleick's actions well. Heartland has a well known track record for supporting for anti-science views regarding the dangers second hand smoke and climate change. Further, Bast and others at Heartland have views and have taken actions that are nasty and and unethical (e.g's; recent billboards comparing climate scientists to the Unabomber and (oh yeah) the very documents that Gleick received).

The Times has (for reasons that I can't begin to fathom) given credulous,"ink" to the Heartland's bogus, denier-fest-ey Climate Conference (articles and blog posts by John Tierney and Andy). Given the degree to which Heartland has a well established record of being an anti-science and bad actor, one is left to wonder why this coverage happened at all.

So what are the take-aways from all this? Andy's "principled" stand:
1. Andy is harshly critical of a highly regarded, top-notch scientist for whistleblowing an anti-science, pro-industry advocacy group. To me, the worst that could be said about Gleick is that he was wearing and investigative journalist hat while Andy feels that it's not OK for a scientist to EVAH put that hat on.
2. In effect, Andy diverts attention from the profound damage done by the Heartland's anti-science advocacy and slandering of reputable scientists.

This on the "Science" pages of the NYT????
Shouldn't you be helping readers know, as best as possible, the truth??? Ain't what you're doing.

@ Steven,
For at least a couple of decades, many top-notch scientists have noted that the Heartland institute has done profound damage by tirelessly promoting discredited science and purposefully muddying the waters of policy discussions extending from current state of the art, climate science. Some scientists have taken bold action to stop this threat. Officious rule-following becomes unimportant when you are confident of moral righteousness and pursuit of truth. So we should applaud Gleick for his actions.

There are reasons why we have whistleblower laws - to protect the small guy who exposes bad actors who have undue power and influence.
---

It is not unreasonable at all to speculate that they really, really had to find some way to get him back.

And I'll admit that I'm inching towards ad hominem here, something I normally detest, but this guy by his own actions and (partial) confession has more than earned it.

On the contrary.  Your repeated insistence that the best scientists are criminals is a wholesale revelation about how closed your mind is.  There is no evidence that will satisfy your desire to destroy and/or ignore the truth and facts.

Andy:

Your response to Mike Roddy misses the point. The use of deceit or the breaking of laws to further moral causes is not contingent on "terms of impact," as you state. (See, e.g., the writings of Ghandi, Martin Luther King, John Rawls, and case law regarding non–violent civil disobedience) Rather, the use hinges on (1)whether a citizen believes moral wrongs are being committed and all other means of righting the wrongs are (essentially) exhausted, and (2)whether a citizen believes he/she has an ethical duty to try to redress the wrongs even if doing so is against prevailing custom or laws.

I would like to believe that, increasingly, more people concerned about mitigating global climate change will understand these points and be more willing to adopt unconventional actions to address the immediate and long–term threats of global climate change. Simply adhering to conventional customs and laws has not worked, and if one believes the science we are close to being out of time to adopt meaningful actions. (see: http://www.int-res.com/abstracts/esep/v11/n1/)

Dr. John Lemons
Professor Emeritus of Biology and Environmental Science
Department of Environmental Studies
University of New England
Biddeford, ME 04005
